titleStmt.title: Most welcome nevves from York being a true and perfect relation of what hath happened in York, since his Majesties last declaration. The Parliaments resolution, concerning the Kings most excellent Majesty, and the Lords and Commons which have absented themselves from the said Houses, and are now at York attending on his Majesty. Likewise the grounds and reasons why they are enforced to take arms, with the severall reasons to prove that every man is bound to uphold the Parliament against all opposers whatsoever. Ordered by the Lords and Commons that this be printed and published Iohn Brown Cler. parl. H. Elsing Cler. parl.
titleStmt.author: Andrews, Edward, fl. 1642.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 8 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

The Parliaments resolution, concerning the Kings most excellent Majesty, and the Lords and Commons which have absented themselves from the said Houses, and are now at York attending on his Majesty. Variant: the words "The Parliaments resolution .. H. Elsing Cler. parl." in title are replaced with "also the faithfull service of the Lord Paget .. and the discovery therof."; no text on verso of title page; partial resetting of type on A4r.

Reproductions of the originals in the British Library (reel 1804) and Folger Shakespeare Library (reel 2409).

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: MOST WELCOME NEWES FROM YORK BEING A true and perfect Relation of what hath happened in York, ≈øince his Maje≈øties la≈øt DECLARATION. The Parliaments Re≈øolution, concerning the Kings mo≈øt excellent Maje≈øty, and the Lords and Commons which have ab≈øented them≈øelves from the ≈øaid Hou≈øes, and are now at York attending on his Maje≈øty. Likewi≈øe the Grounds and Rea≈øons why they are enforced to take Arms, With the ≈øeverall Rea≈øons to prove that every man is bound to uphold the Parliament again≈øt all Oppo≈øers what≈øoever.

p.hi: Ordered by the Lords and Commons that this be printed and publi≈øhed.

closer.signed: Iohn Brown Cler. parl. H. El≈øing Cler. parl.

div.head: The Rea≈øon why the Subiect is bound to obey the Command of the Parliament, Voted,
div.p: That if in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity, if his Maje≈øty ≈øhall deny his a≈ø≈øent, the Ordinance agreed on by both Hou≈øes of Parliament, doth obliege the People, and ought to bee obeyed, being warranted by the Fundamentall Laws of the Kingdome.

Both Hou≈øes of Parliament hath took into their ≈øerious con≈øideratio ‚Ä¢ the Occa≈øion and Rea≈øon why the Members of the ≈øaid Hou≈øes ≈øhould ab≈øent them≈øelves upon their ≈øummoning in, Wherupon they hath drawn up a ‚Ä¢ harge again≈øt them, and are re≈øolv'd that they ≈øhall pay 100. l. a man, and to be examined by the Committee before the next ≈øitting.

p.hi: Ordered by the Lords and Commons in Parliament, that this be printed and publi≈øhed,

list.item: Hen, El≈øing Cler. Parl D. Com.

div.head: WELCOME NEWES FROM YORK:
div.p: I Cannot without the fearfull and terrible ≈øtain of ingratitude forget your abundance of love, expre≈ø≈øed unto me when you were re≈øident with us here in the North.
It was your de≈øire, and your courte≈øie to me, and my great nece≈ø≈øity have engaged me to certifie you of all Pa≈ø≈øages which have bin worth any ob≈øervation ≈øince your departure from us.

The common fear is of wars, ‚Ä¢ nd that fear is ≈øo farre publi≈øht throughout the
whole County, that we mu≈øt hope little le≈øse can en≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ .
His Maje≈øty will not give leave to any conditions, but what he hath him≈øelf fir≈øt propo≈øed.
Some Lords do encourage his Re≈øolutions, but the others ≈øtand as Neutrals rather endeavouring to per≈øwade him, then to encourage his Re≈øolution in the violent way of war.

We hear that my Lord Pagets ab≈øence from the Hou≈øe, which was beyond expectation, hath much di≈øcontented the Hou≈øe, but here his intentions are found to be ≈øo faithfull, that wee hope they will have no ground to que≈øtion his fidelity and tru≈øt.

There came lately to York many Cavaleers from London, who offered to maintain His Majs≈øties Re≈øolution of ≈øetting up His Standard, from which ≈øome well di≈øpo≈øed Lords of His Maje≈øties Coun≈øell, did of late did of late di≈ø≈øure him. The≈øe Cavaleers at a place called Grim≈øton within 12. miles of Yorke,
upon the 16. of June did gather a head, being in number above three≈øcore, and in the ≈øpace of three hours by their fain in≈øinuation had gathered unto them a great multitude more, in this Confu≈øion they pa≈ø≈øed towards Yorke City, and at their fir≈øt comming they did pre≈øent their ≈øervice unto His Maje≈øty, as men willing to continue this mi≈øerable di≈øtraction, their whole intents complying with his Maje≈øties Re≈øolution of ≈øetting up his Standard.

Upon their fir≈øt proffer, his Maje≈øty was much moved and heavie, de≈øired to have ≈øome time for re≈øpite for their Entertainment, but did the next morning being the 17. of JUNE entertain mo≈øt of them, which hath given them mo≈øt ≈øtrange and mighty Encouragement.
I will give you for your better ≈øati≈øfaction ≈øome of their Names, which have bin the main Agents in this cau≈øe, but ere long I hope they will be apprehended.
Collonel Williams Capt, Draper. Capt. Early. Capt. Stichborn, Lievtenant Gilbert, Sergeant Major Smith, and ≈øome others, Thus I re≈øt,

closer.signed: Your mo≈øt obliged Friend, EDWARD ANDREWS.

div.p:
SInce the peace of this Kingdome hath bin di≈øturbed, tho≈øe dangerous Agents of Rome hath practi≈øed many de≈øperate Attempts again≈øt this Nation; Whereby they have indeavoured the ≈øubver≈øion of our Liberties and per≈øons, And ≈øince all the≈øe now within the≈øe few dayes there aro≈øe a ≈øtrange and mo≈øt wicked danger in Darby Towne, where by the motion and in≈øtigation of one Ma≈øter John Ham≈øon a Catholique, ≈øtrange things have happened, for after that he and his adherents had indeavoured to ≈øpoyle one Mr. James his hou≈øe, when their intentions
did not take ≈øuch ≈øucce≈øse as they expected, they entred the ≈øame James his hou≈øe, and not finding him at home, ≈øeized upon his wife; whom after they had ravi≈øhed, they gagged in a mo≈øt terrible manner: and after this mi≈øchief they plundered the hou≈øe, and told her that this was but the beginning of what they did intend to act.

p.hi: This ≈ølept for a ≈øea≈øon, and within a ≈ømall ≈øpace they intended to fire the Towne, but by the information of Mi≈øtris James his wife, their fartqer mi≈øchief was prevented, and all their De≈øigns countermanded.
Thus the Actors were di≈øcovered, and all things now brought to light, which they intended ≈øhould have bin brought to a greater light.

div.p: By vertue of an Order this day made in the Hou≈øe of Commons Iune 17. the Officers and Keformadoes li≈øted by the Adventurers for Ireland, are hereby required to take notice, that they are on tue≈øday next (at 9. a clock in the morning) to hear a Sermon, and take the Prote≈øtation at St. Laurence Church neer Guild-Hall London, and then to enter into pay at Guild-Hall afore≈øaid.

div.head: A Command from the High Court of Parliament, to the Ju≈øtices of Peace neer adjoyning to the Northern Roads.
div.p: IT is this day ordered by the Lords in Parliament a≈ø≈øembled, That a ≈øtrict ≈øearch and Examination be made by the Ju≈øtices of peace Maior, Bayliffs, Con≈øtables, and other his Maje≈øties Officers, inhabiting, or neer adjoyning to all the Northerne Roads, for the ≈øtopping and ≈øtaying of all Armes, Ammunition, Powder, Light-hor≈øes, or hor≈øes for ≈øervice in the Warres, and great Saddles that are, or ≈øhal be carryed towards the North parts of England, but by the privity and direction of one, or both Hou≈øes of Parliament; And that the ≈øaid Officers ≈øhall ≈øtay them accordingly, and ≈øpeedily give information thereof unto one of the Hou≈øes of Parliament.
Ordered by the Lords in Parliament. That this ≈øhall be printed and publi≈øhed.
